unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Admissions Test
question_text:
State University applicants are required to take an admission test for entrance into the university.
In a given year, $850\text{ applicants}$ took the test, and the mean score was $68$ with a standard deviation of $4\text{ points}$. Suppose we do not know if the scores are approximately normally distributed.
What can be said about the number of scores that are less than $60$ (to the nearest integer)?

choices.text: At most $2$ of the scores are less than $60$.
At least $20$ of the scores are less than $60$.
Exactly $0.0228$ of the scores are less than $60$.
At least $637$ of the scores are less than $60$.
At most $213$ of the scores are less than $60$.

solution:
We do not know if the scores are normally distributed; therefore, we must use Chebyshev’s rule. Since $68-k(4) = 60$, then $k = 2$.

As such, at most
1
4
=25% of the scores are less than 60. We know that 850 students took the test, so there are at most (0.25)(850)=212.5 or 213 scores less than 60. This is the best approximation we can make since we do not know if the distribution is normally distributed.

It may be that far fewer than 213 students fall below a 60, but we cannot make that statement without the assumption of a normal distribution. Chebyshev’s rule must be used in this instance.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'
